content.raw:
This portion of code involves processing a list of both tracks as strings and file objects (containing lists of tracks). I'm not sure what the best variable name in this case would be.

The reason why this even came to be in the first place is this was normally automatically done by the optplus module (the lines from the files were automatically appeneded to the list) but had to be avoided when migrating over to argparse.
content.html:
This portion of code involves processing a list of both tracks as strings and file objects (containing lists of tracks). I'm not sure what the best variable name in this case would be.

The reason why this even came to be in the first place is this was normally automatically done by the optplus module (the lines from the files were automatically appeneded to the list) but had to be avoided when migrating over to argparse.

content.raw:
The two options of handling this code are either to check the object type (with something like isinstance) or to try to read a file-like object and catch the exception when it is not a file. However, In Python 3 you cannot use:
```python
isinstance(track_object, file)
```
See https://docs.python.org/release/3.0/whatsnew/3.0.html#builtins

Another option would to be to use something like hasattr(track_object, read) to see if the object is "file-like" and readable.
content.html:
The two options of handling this code are either to check the object type (with something like isinstance) or to try to read a file-like object and catch the exception when it is not a file. However, In Python 3 you cannot use:

isinstance(track_object, file)

See https://docs.python.org/release/3.0/whatsnew/3.0.html#builtins

Another option would to be to use something like hasattr(track_object, read) to see if the object is "file-like" and readable.

content.raw: Is this necessary?
content.html: Is this necessary?

content.raw:
So in trying to make the optparse/argparse as close to a 1:1 migration as possible I had to try to separate the "options" from the "arguments". ArgumentParser makes no distinction and throws all arguments into a big `Namespace` object which I believe is simple subclass of the base `Object` class.

This deletion is **probably** not necessary. In making the port I wanted to be as safe as possible and make sure that the "options" and the "arguments" were cleanly separated like they were before with optparse. This means taking out the "args" into it's own variable and removing the "args" attribute from the "options".
content.html:
So in trying to make the optparse/argparse as close to a 1:1 migration as possible I had to try to separate the "options" from the "arguments". ArgumentParser makes no distinction and throws all arguments into a big Namespace object which I believe is simple subclass of the base Object class.

This deletion is probably not necessary. In making the port I wanted to be as safe as possible and make sure that the "options" and the "arguments" were cleanly separated like they were before with optparse. This means taking out the "args" into it's own variable and removing the "args" attribute from the "options".

content.raw:
This is all a bit confusing. How about:

1) rename the argument to this to be `argv` instead of `args` so we stop reusing it to mean different things

Then:

```
#!python

options = parser.parse_args(argv)
args = options.args
```

Is it necessary to `del options.args` afterwards? Because it looks like it is not.
